docs.abstract: Lift that flap, peek through that hole, press that button. Interactive books keep little ones entertained — and help them develop cognitive abilities.
docs.snippet: Lift that flap, peek through that hole, press that button. Interactive books keep little ones entertained — and help them develop cognitive abilities.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes I, a full-grown adult, see a so-called lift-the-flap book, meant for babies and toddlers, and become almost tingly with the desire to feel those cardboard tabs under my fingers and discover what’s hidden behind each one. It makes me suspect that interactive board books hit some primal sweet spot — and literacy research, it turns out, backs up my instinct. Our brains evolved to seek out and benefit from “multisensory” experiences, especially when our cognitive abilities are still developing. Young children exposed to books that engage more than one sense tend to have better comprehension and enthusiasm for reading down the road.

headline.main: Books That Captivate Babies and Toddlers

docs.abstract: His rich melodies and powerful lyrics, also heard in “Mame” and “La Cage aux Folles,” dazzled critics and kept audiences returning for more.
docs.snippet: His rich melodies and powerful lyrics, also heard in “Mame” and “La Cage aux Folles,” dazzled critics and kept audiences returning for more.

headline.main: Jerry Herman, Composer of ‘Hello, Dolly!’ and Other Broadway Hits, Dies at 88
headline.print_headline: Jerry Herman, 88, Composer of ‘Hello, Dolly!’ and Other Broadway Hits, Dies

docs.abstract: Harvey Fierstein, Betty Buckley and more on the sunny songwriter behind “Hello, Dolly!” and “Mame,” who hoped that even a flop would find a second life.
docs.snippet: Harvey Fierstein, Betty Buckley and more on the sunny songwriter behind “Hello, Dolly!” and “Mame,” who hoped that even a flop would find a second life.
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone described Jerry Herman as an optimist. And certainly the Broadway songwriter, who died Thursday at 88, had reason to look on the bright side: “Hello, Dolly!,” “Mame” and “La Cage aux Folles,” to name his biggest hits, each ran for more than 1,500 performances, the last winning the best musical Tony Award three times (twice for its revivals).

headline.main: Remembering Jerry Herman: ‘He Called His Shows His Children’

docs.abstract: A brassy celebration of optimism and urbanity, “Put on Your Sunday Clothes” from “Hello, Dolly!” can still stir the emotions.
docs.snippet: A brassy celebration of optimism and urbanity, “Put on Your Sunday Clothes” from “Hello, Dolly!” can still stir the emotions.
docs.lead_paragraph: Every time I pass the Yonkers train station, during my Metro North commute between Manhattan and my upstate home, a song by Jerry Herman, who died on Thursday at 88, starts playing in my head. It is a sacred song, more resonant for me than any hymn I learned in my churchgoing childhood. And there are lyrics in it that, if I linger on them, automatically bring tears to my eyes.

headline.main: How a Jerry Herman Song Called a Future Critic to New York
headline.print_headline: The Fantasies and Gasps Jerry Herman’s Songs Inspired

docs.abstract: The season sparkles at seven holiday light displays across New York City.
docs.snippet: The season sparkles at seven holiday light displays across New York City.
docs.lead_paragraph: April may be the cruelest month, but December, the darkest, can feel unkind, too. New York, however, offers its own illumination during these long, blustery nights, and not just Rockefeller Center’s seasonal sparkle. Here’s a guide to some of the lavish light displays across the city, including twinkling and towering sculptures, Chinese-style lantern shows and giant menorahs. You will usually find food, entertainment and family activities here, as well as glowing LED artifice: fairy palaces, alluring sweets, roaring dinosaurs — and lots of pandas.

docs.abstract: Once the envy of others, the U.S. is more likely to be scrutinized these days.
docs.snippet: Once the envy of others, the U.S. is more likely to be scrutinized these days.
docs.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — HAVING lived and worked abroad for many years, I’m sensitive to the changing ways that foreigners look at America. Over the years, I’ve seen an America that was respected, hated, feared and loved. But traveling around China and Singapore last week, I was confronted repeatedly with an attitude toward America that I’ve never heard before: “What’s up with you guys?”

headline.main: Calling America: Hello? Hello? Hello? Hello?
headline.print_headline: Calling America: Hello? Hello? Hello? Hello?

docs.abstract: Though President Reagan is abroad, contacts between the White House and the outside world continue unabated. Following are some recent insights into how the Administration's fabled communications apparatus operates or, upon occasion, does not operate:    * Thomas S. Kahn, a former Congressional aide who is now a New York city lawyer, was eager to convey his views on the President's Bitburg visit to a White House official of some consequence, so he telephoned Patrick J. Buchanan, director of communications. According to Mr. Kahn, a White House switchboard operator on successive calls placed him on indefinite hold, connected him to a recording and gave him an argument when he tried to leave a message. Finally, he placed a person-to-person call and left his name and number. Shortly thereafter, the phone in his Manhattan apartment rang, and the caller asked: ''May I speak to President Reagan?'' A few minutes later, there was another call for the President. Protesting later to the White House, Mr. Kahn said he was told that a maintenance man had been temporarily tending the switchboard that morning. Independent inquiry this week produced an official who attributed the errant phone calls to ''malfunctioning equipment.''
docs.lead_paragraph: Though President Reagan is abroad, contacts between the White House and the outside world continue unabated. Following are some recent insights into how the Administration's fabled communications apparatus operates or, upon occasion, does not operate:

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

docs.abstract: Designers are creating matching outfits for dogs and humans; photo (Pulse column) (M)
docs.snippet: Designers are creating matching outfits for dogs and humans; photo (Pulse column) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In a quirky take on mother-daughter matching outfits, mainstream clothing and pet apparel designers are creating complementary ensembles for humans and dogs. At Kate Spade, a raincoat ($395), rain hat ($110) and dog coat ($125), right, are emblazoned with identical Maira Kalman prints. Coach has the Down Jacket for women ($398) and Puffa vest for dogs, both trimmed in matching leather ($148). Fifi & Romeo offers a red cashmere dog sweater ($225), decorated with a large bone, while a matching human-size hat and scarf ($195 and $175) sport the same design (all at Kirna Zabête, 212-941-9656). From Wag Wear a merino dog sweater ($110), in heather gray with red color block or pink with green color block, has a biped-cut counterpart: a unisex zip-front cardigan with raglan sleeves in the contrasting color ($275, both at www.wagwear.com). And the Nordic Sweater from Land's End is available for men, women, children and dogs ($14 to 49.50, www.landsend.com) so that the whole family can match its Fair Isle. JENNIFER LAING
